### Article r√©√©crit

## üåü **Meta Connect 2025 : Mark Zuckerberg d√©voile trois nouvelles paires de lunettes intelligentes**

Lors de l'√©v√©nement **Meta Connect 2025**, le plus grand √©v√©nement de l'ann√©e de l'entreprise, **Mark Zuckerberg** a d√©voil√© trois nouvelles paires de **lunettes intelligentes** : les **Ray-Ban Meta de deuxi√®me g√©n√©ration**, les **Meta Ray-Ban Display** avec un **bracelet de contr√¥le**, et les **Oakley Meta Vanguard**.

Meta affirme avoir vendu **deux millions** de paires de la premi√®re g√©n√©ration des **Ray-Ban Meta**, et plus t√¥t cette ann√©e, Meta a d√©voil√© ses derni√®res lunettes intelligentes aliment√©es par l'IA avec **Oakley**, con√ßues pour les athl√®tes. La **Silicon Valley** mise fortement sur les **wearables** aliment√©s par l'IA, et Meta semble √™tre l'une des entreprises √† la pointe de cette tendance.

## üé§ **D√©monstration rat√©e de l'IA**

Alors que Meta cherchait √† regagner du terrain dans la course √† l'IA et √† vendre plus de mat√©riel, l'entreprise avait beaucoup en jeu lors de la keynote de Mark Zuckerberg √† **Meta Connect 2025**. Globalement, Meta a pr√©sent√© des technologies assez impressionnantes ‚Äî le **Meta Neural Band**, le bracelet de contr√¥le qui accompagne les **Meta Ray-Ban Display**, est particuli√®rement remarquable.

Cependant, dans un rebondissement qui rappelait **HBO‚Äôs Silicon Valley**, la d√©mo des capacit√©s d'IA sur les **Ray-Ban Metas** a √©chou√©. **Whoops!**

En partageant un flux vid√©o en direct du cr√©ateur de contenu culinaire **Jack Mancuso** au si√®ge de Meta, Zuckerberg a demand√© au chef de d√©montrer comment ses **Ray-Ban Meta** pouvaient l'aider √† pr√©parer une sauce pour steak inspir√©e de la Cor√©e.

¬´ J'aime la configuration que vous avez ici, avec de la sauce soja et d'autres ingr√©dients. Comment puis-je vous aider ? ¬ª a demand√© la voix enjou√©e de **Meta AI**.

Mancuso a demand√© une recette pour une sauce pour steak inspir√©e de la Cor√©e, et la voix de l'IA a commenc√© √† lister les ingr√©dients dont il aurait besoin ‚Äî mais Mancuso sait qu'il doit garder la d√©mo succincte, alors il interrompt et demande : ¬´ Que dois-je faire en premier ? ¬ª

Apr√®s un moment de silence qui a dur√© un peu trop longtemps, Mancuso a r√©p√©t√© : ¬´ Que dois-je faire en premier ? ¬ª

¬´ Vous avez d√©j√† combin√© les ingr√©dients de base, alors maintenant, r√¢pez une poire pour l'ajouter √† la sauce ¬ª, a dit l'IA. Mais il n'avait pas encore combin√© les ingr√©dients de base, car il n'avait pas commenc√© √† pr√©parer la recette, d'o√π la question de savoir quoi faire en premier.

Mancuso a pos√© la m√™me question √† nouveau, et l'IA a donn√© la m√™me r√©ponse. Le public a ri.

¬´ Je pense que le Wi-Fi doit √™tre en panne ‚Äî retour √† toi Mark ! ¬ª a dit Mancuso.

¬´ Vous savez quoi ? Tout va bien. Le c√¥t√© ironique de tout cela est que vous passez des ann√©es √† cr√©er la technologie, et puis le Wi-Fi du jour vous attrape ¬ª, a dit Zuckerberg. ¬´ En tout cas, nous irons voir ce qu'il a pr√©par√© plus tard. ¬ª

L'interaction √©tait un peu g√™nante, surtout puisque le probl√®me ne semblait pas √™tre li√© au Wi-Fi. Mais m√™me lorsque les choses se passent selon le plan, ces pr√©sentations peuvent sembler un peu artificielles‚Ä¶ comme √† la fin de la keynote, lorsque Zuckerberg et **Diplo** ont litt√©ralement couru vers le coucher du soleil ensemble, portant leurs **Meta Oakley Vanguards**. Cela a d√ª √™tre une journ√©e charg√©e pour Mark, alors peut-√™tre avait-il juste besoin d'une excuse pour int√©grer un peu de cardio √† son emploi du temps.

## üëì **Deuxi√®me g√©n√©ration des Ray-Ban Meta**

Meta a d√©voil√© la deuxi√®me g√©n√©ration de ses **Ray-Ban Meta**, qui ont fait leur premi√®re apparition en **2023**. Ce mod√®le am√©lior√© offre **le double** de l'autonomie de son pr√©d√©cesseur, maintenant jusqu'√† **huit heures** d'utilisation mixte sur une seule charge. Les lunettes de deuxi√®me g√©n√©ration prennent √©galement en charge l'enregistrement vid√©o **ultra HD 3K**, que l'entreprise affirme √™tre **deux fois plus net** que le mod√®le pr√©c√©dent.

Les **Ray-Ban Meta** de deuxi√®me g√©n√©ration sont √©galement dot√©es de nouvelles fonctionnalit√©s, comme la **concentration conversationnelle**, qui sera disponible sur les **Ray-Ban Meta** et les **Oakley Meta HSTN**.

¬´ Si vous mangez dans un nouveau restaurant branch√©, que vous commutez en train, ou que vous √©coutez le dernier set de votre DJ pr√©f√©r√©, la concentration conversationnelle utilise les haut-parleurs √† oreille ouverte de vos lunettes intelligentes pour amplifier la voix de la personne √† qui vous parlez ¬ª, a d√©clar√© Meta dans son communiqu√© de presse.

La **concentration conversationnelle** n'est pas encore disponible, donc nous ne pouvons pas dire avec certitude si elle sera utile pour votre prochaine sortie.

La fonctionnalit√© **Live AI** ‚Äî que Meta a √©chou√© √† d√©montrer correctement sur sc√®ne ‚Äî est √©galement en route. Mais elle est si √©nergivore que vous ne pouvez l'utiliser que pendant environ **une heure ou deux**.

¬´ √Ä mesure que nous optimisons l'efficacit√© √©nerg√©tique et la batterie, **Meta AI** passera d'une assistance que vous activez avec une phrase d'√©veil √† une assistance toujours disponible ¬ª, a d√©clar√© l'entreprise.

Les **Ray-Ban Meta** de deuxi√®me g√©n√©ration sont propos√©es √† **379 $**.

## üåü **Meta Ray-Ban Display et Meta Neural Band**

Les **Meta Ray-Ban Display** sont les lunettes les plus impressionnantes que Meta ait d√©voil√©es √† ce jour, avec un **affichage int√©gr√©** pour les applications, les alertes et les directions sur la lentille droite. Mais ce qui distingue cette paire de lunettes intelligentes est son **bracelet de contr√¥le** accompagnant, le **Meta Neural Band**.

Ce bracelet permet √† Meta de montrer un peu ce sur quoi elle a pass√© tant de temps (et d'argent) dans sa division **Reality Labs**, connue pour perdre des milliards de dollars par trimestre.

Visuellement, le **Meta Neural Band** ressemble √† un **Fitbit** sans √©cran. Il est aliment√© par **l'√©lectromyographie de surface (sEMG)**, qui peut d√©tecter des gestes de la main et des mouvements minuscules. Cela est bien plus sophistiqu√© qu'un geste du poignet sur une **Apple Watch**. Les utilisateurs peuvent √©crire des messages texte en tenant leurs doigts ensemble comme s'ils tenaient un stylo et en ¬´ √©crivant ¬ª le texte. Cela signifie que vous pouvez voir un message **WhatsApp** arriver sur votre lentille de lunettes droite, puis y r√©pondre en ¬´ √©crivant ¬ª votre r√©ponse.

Pour l'instant, les lunettes prennent en charge les applications **Meta**, mais l'entreprise devra prendre en charge une grande vari√©t√© d'applications √† l'avenir pour obtenir l'adoption qu'elle recherche. Comme **Apple** et **Google**, Meta mise sur le fait que les **lunettes intelligentes** pourraient grignoter la part de march√© des **smartphones** √† l'avenir ‚Äî mais ce sera un d√©fi de taille pour forcer un tel changement culturel massif.

Les **Meta Ray-Ban Display**, qui incluent le **Meta Neural Band**, co√ªteront **799 $** et seront disponibles √† partir du **30 septembre**.

## üèÉ **Oakley Meta Vanguard : pour les athl√®tes**

Pour les plus sceptiques, il est difficile d'imaginer porter des **lunettes intelligentes** et envoyer des messages texte en √©crivant dans l'air. Mais les **Oakley Meta Vanguard**, con√ßues pour les athl√®tes, offrent le cas d'utilisation le plus coh√©rent √† ce jour pour ce type de technologie.

Les **cyclistes, trail runners et skieurs** peuvent photographier leurs aventures sans sortir leur t√©l√©phone ; les haut-parleurs √† air ouvert des lunettes peuvent jouer de la musique pendant votre s√©ance d'entra√Ænement, et m√™me se lier avec des applications comme **Strava** et **Garmin** pour relayer vos statistiques. Comme les autres nouveaux mod√®les de lunettes, le mod√®le **Vanguard** est √©galement aliment√© par l'IA.

Contrairement aux autres mod√®les de **lunettes intelligentes Meta**, les **Oakley Meta Vanguard** ont une seule lentille avant unifi√©e avec une cam√©ra au milieu, plut√¥t que deux lentilles avec des cam√©ras de chaque c√¥t√© ‚Äî c'est un design qui a plus de sens sur le plan technique, et c'est une d√©claration de mode que vous pouvez porter dans des lunettes de sport, mais pas dans des lunettes (prouvez-moi le contraire). Les nouvelles lunettes peuvent capturer des vid√©os jusqu'en **3K** et sont √©quip√©es d'un **appareil photo de 12 m√©gapixels** avec un **objectif grand-angle de 122 degr√©s**.

Les lunettes ont une **r√©sistance √† la poussi√®re et √† l'eau IP67** pour une utilisation pendant les entra√Ænements intenses. Meta affirme que le design enveloppant des lunettes est √©quip√© de la technologie **Oakley PRIZM‚Ñ¢ Lens**, con√ßue pour bloquer le soleil, le vent et la poussi√®re.

√Ä moins que vous ne soyez un **ultra-marathonien**, ces lunettes dureront facilement tout au long de votre entra√Ænement. Les lunettes peuvent rester allum√©es pendant **neuf heures**, ou **six heures** avec une lecture musicale continue. Mais le **bo√Ætier de charge** qui accompagne les lunettes peut fournir une charge suppl√©mentaire de **36 heures** en d√©placement. Meta affirme que le bo√Ætier de charge peut rapidement amener les lunettes √† **50 % de charge** en **20 minutes**.

Les **Oakley Meta Vanguard** sont propos√©es √† **499 $** et seront disponibles √† partir du **21 octobre**.

## üï∂Ô∏è **Mises √† jour VR**

C√¥t√© **VR**, Meta n'a pas lanc√© de nouveaux casques **Quest** lors de cette ann√©e **Connect**. Bien que la conf√©rence, et l'entreprise, portent le nom du **Metaverse**, nous avons appris qu'un petit nombre de mises √† jour de sa **VR**, comme **Hyperscape**, permettront aux d√©veloppeurs et cr√©ateurs de construire des espaces **photorealistes** en r√©alit√© virtuelle.

Meta d√©veloppe apparemment un **casque VR ultral√©ger** pour un lancement d'ici la fin de **2026**, alors peut-√™tre verrons-nous cela se concr√©tiser lors du prochain √©v√©nement **Meta Connect**.

title: Silicon Valley bets big on ‚Äòenvironments‚Äô to train AI agents
content:
### R√©sum√©
Les PDG des grandes entreprises technologiques ont longtemps √©voqu√© des visions d'agents IA capables d'utiliser des logiciels pour accomplir des t√¢ches de mani√®re autonome. Cependant, les agents IA actuels, comme ceux d'OpenAI et de Perplexity, restent tr√®s limit√©s. Pour am√©liorer ces agents, une nouvelle technique √©merge : la simulation d'espaces de travail pour entra√Æner les agents sur des t√¢ches complexes, appel√©e environnements d'apprentissage par renforcement (RL). Les laboratoires d'IA et les startups investissent massivement dans ces environnements, esp√©rant qu'ils deviendront aussi cruciaux que les jeux de donn√©es √©tiquet√©s pour les progr√®s de l'IA.

### Article r√©√©crit

## ü§ñ **Les agents IA : une technologie encore limit√©e**

Pourtant, les agents IA actuels, comme ceux d'OpenAI et de Perplexity, restent tr√®s limit√©s. Pour am√©liorer ces agents, une nouvelle technique √©merge : la simulation d'espaces de travail pour entra√Æner les agents sur des t√¢ches complexes, appel√©e **environnements d'apprentissage par renforcement (RL)**.

## üß† **Les environnements d'apprentissage par renforcement (RL)**

Les environnements d'apprentissage par renforcement (RL) sont des terrains d'entra√Ænement qui simulent ce qu'un agent IA ferait dans une application logicielle r√©elle. Par exemple, un environnement pourrait simuler un navigateur Chrome et demander √† un agent IA d'acheter une paire de chaussettes sur Amazon. L'agent est not√© sur sa performance et re√ßoit un signal de r√©compense lorsqu'il r√©ussit.

## üèóÔ∏è **La complexit√© des environnements RL**

Cependant, la construction de ces environnements est bien plus complexe que la cr√©ation de jeux de donn√©es statiques. Les d√©veloppeurs ne peuvent pas pr√©dire exactement les erreurs qu'un agent pourrait commettre, donc l'environnement doit √™tre robuste pour capturer tout comportement inattendu et fournir des retours utiles.

## üí° **Les acteurs cl√©s du march√©**

### üè¢ **Les grands laboratoires d'IA**

Les grands laboratoires d'IA, comme OpenAI et Anthropic, investissent massivement dans les environnements RL. Anthropic envisage m√™me de d√©penser plus d'un milliard de dollars dans ces environnements au cours de l'ann√©e prochaine.

### üöÄ **Les startups innovantes**

Plusieurs startups, comme **Mechanize** et **Prime Intellect**, se positionnent comme leaders dans ce domaine. Ces startups visent √† fournir des environnements RL de haute qualit√© pour entra√Æner les agents IA.

### üìà **Les entreprises de labellisation de donn√©es**

Des entreprises comme **Scale AI**, **Surge** et **Mercor** investissent √©galement dans les environnements RL pour r√©pondre √† la demande croissante des laboratoires d'IA.

## üîç **Les d√©fis et les opportunit√©s**

### ü§î **Les sceptiques**

Certains experts, comme Ross Taylor, ancien responsable de la recherche en IA chez Meta, mettent en garde contre les difficult√©s de mise √† l'√©chelle des environnements RL. Ils soulignent que les mod√®les IA peuvent tricher pour obtenir des r√©compenses sans vraiment accomplir la t√¢che.

### üåü **Les optimistes**

D'autres, comme Andrej Karpathy, investisseur dans Prime Intellect, voient les environnements RL comme une avanc√©e majeure. Ils croient que ces environnements permettront de faire progresser l'IA de mani√®re significative.

## üìÖ **Conclusion**

Les environnements d'apprentissage par renforcement (RL) repr√©sentent une nouvelle fronti√®re dans le d√©veloppement des agents IA. Bien que les d√©fis soient nombreux, les investissements massifs et les innovations des startups laissent entrevoir un avenir prometteur pour cette technologie.

title: CodeRabbit raises $60M, valuing the 2-year-old AI code review startup at $550M
content:
### R√©sum√©
Harjot Gill, fondateur de CodeRabbit, a remarqu√© que l'adoption croissante des assistants de codage IA comme GitHub Copilot cr√©ait des goulots d'√©tranglement dans les revues de code. Il a donc lanc√© CodeRabbit, une plateforme de revue de code aliment√©e par l'IA, qui a connu une croissance rapide et a r√©cemment lev√© 60 millions de dollars en s√©rie B. CodeRabbit aide les entreprises √† identifier les bugs et √† r√©duire de moiti√© le nombre de revues de code humaines, bien que la concurrence dans ce domaine soit forte.

### Article r√©√©crit

#### üöÄ **L'essor de CodeRabbit : Une r√©volution dans la revue de code**

Harjot Gill, ancien co-fondateur de **FluxNinja**, une startup sp√©cialis√©e dans l'**observabilit√©**, a remarqu√© une tendance int√©ressante. **"Nous avions une √©quipe d'ing√©nieurs √† distance qui commen√ßaient √† adopter l'**IA** pour la g√©n√©ration de code sur **GitHub Copilot**,"** a-t-il d√©clar√© √† **TechCrunch**. **"Nous avons vu cette adoption se produire, et il √©tait tr√®s clair pour moi que, comme effet secondaire, cela allait causer des goulots d'√©tranglement dans la revue de code."**

En **2023**, Gill a lanc√© **CodeRabbit**, une plateforme de **revue de code aliment√©e par l'IA**, et a acquis **FlexNinja**. Sa pr√©diction s'est av√©r√©e exacte : les d√©veloppeurs utilisent d√©sormais r√©guli√®rement des assistants de codage IA, mais le code g√©n√©r√© est souvent bugu√©, for√ßant les ing√©nieurs √† passer beaucoup de temps √† corriger les erreurs.

#### üõ†Ô∏è **Comment CodeRabbit fonctionne-t-il ?**

CodeRabbit peut aider √† d√©tecter certaines de ces erreurs. L'entreprise a connu une croissance de **20% par mois** et g√©n√®re d√©sormais plus de **15 millions de dollars** de **revenus r√©currents annuels (ARR)**, selon Gill.

#### üí∞ **Une lev√©e de fonds impressionnante**

Les investisseurs sont enthousiasm√©s par la croissance de la startup. **Mardi, CodeRabbit a annonc√© avoir lev√© 60 millions de dollars** lors d'un tour de table de **s√©rie B**, valorisant l'entreprise √† **550 millions de dollars**. Ce tour, qui porte le total des fonds lev√©s √† **88 millions de dollars**, a √©t√© men√© par **Scale Venture Partners**, avec la participation de **NVentures**, le bras de capital-risque de **Nvidia**, et d'investisseurs r√©currents comme **CRV**.

#### üè¢ **Des clients prestigieux**

CodeRabbit aide des entreprises comme **Chegg**, **Groupon**, **Mercury**, et plus de **8 000 autres**, √† √©conomiser du temps sur la t√¢che fameusement frustrante de la **revue de code**, devenue encore plus chronophage avec l'essor du code g√©n√©r√© par l'IA.

#### ü§ñ **Une solution intelligente**

Comme **CodeRabbit** comprend la base de code d'une entreprise, il peut identifier les bugs et fournir des commentaires, agissant comme un coll√®gue, a d√©clar√© Gill. **Il ajoute que les entreprises utilisant CodeRabbit peuvent r√©duire de moiti√© le nombre de revues de code humaines.**

#### üèÜ **La concurrence**

Comme dans la plupart des domaines de l'IA, **CodeRabbit** a des concurrents. Parmi les startups rivales, on trouve **Graphite**, qui a lev√© **52 millions de dollars** en s√©rie B, et **Greptile**, qui est en pourparlers pour une lev√©e de **30 millions de dollars** en s√©rie A.

Bien que des assistants de codage leaders comme **Anthropic‚Äôs Claude Code** et **Cursor** offrent √©galement des capacit√©s de **revue de code aliment√©e par l'IA**, Gill mise sur le fait que les clients pr√©f√©reront une offre autonome √† long terme. **"CodeRabbit est beaucoup plus complet en termes de profondeur et de largeur technique que les solutions bundl√©es,"** a-t-il d√©clar√©.

#### üîÆ **L'avenir de la revue de code**

Quelle que soit la pr√©diction de Gill, il est clair que des milliers de d√©veloppeurs sont pr√™ts √† payer **30 dollars par mois** pour utiliser **CodeRabbit**.

M√™me avec la popularit√© croissante des outils de **revue de code IA** comme **CodeRabbit**, les solutions IA ne peuvent pas encore √™tre pleinement fiables pour corriger les bugs et le code "inutilisable" √©crit par l'IA. **L'incertitude du code g√©n√©r√© par l'IA a donn√© naissance √† un nouveau r√¥le corporate : le sp√©cialiste du nettoyage de code "vibe".**

title: Gemini tops the App Store thanks to new AI image model, Nano Banana
content:
### R√©sum√©
L'adoption mobile de **Gemini** a connu une **hausse spectaculaire** depuis le lancement de son mod√®le **Nano Banana** en ao√ªt. L'application a atteint la **premi√®re place** dans les classements des magasins d'applications mondiaux, avec une augmentation de **45%** des t√©l√©chargements en septembre. Gemini a √©galement g√©n√©r√© des revenus significatifs, avec **1,6 million de dollars** en ao√ªt, principalement gr√¢ce √† Nano Banana. L'application a √©t√© t√©l√©charg√©e **103,7 millions de fois** cette ann√©e et **185,4 millions de fois** depuis son lancement.

---

# üöÄ **Gemini‚Äôs Mobile Adoption Soars with Nano Banana Image Editor**

## üìà **Rapid Growth and Top Rankings**

Gemini‚Äôs mobile adoption has been **soaring** since the **August launch** of its **Nano Banana** image editor model, which has received **positive reviews**, particularly from users who say they can now more easily perform **complex edits** and create **realistic images**. The app has climbed to the **top of global app stores‚Äô charts** and has seen a **45% month-over-month increase** in downloads in the month of September so far, according to new data provided by **app intelligence firm Appfigures**.

Though the month is only half over, **Gemini‚Äôs app** has already gained **12.6 million downloads** in September, up from **8.7 million** in August.

## üìä **Historical Performance and Current Rankings**

Before this month, **Gemini** had only gotten as high as **No. 3** on the **U.S. App Store** on **January 28, 2025**.

Shortly after **Nano Banana‚Äôs release**, **Gemini** reached the **No. 2 spot** on the **U.S. App Store** on **September 8**. It then became the **No. 1 app** on **September 12**, where it has remained, after knocking **OpenAI‚Äôs ChatGPT** down to **No. 2**. No other **dedicated AI apps** are in the **top 10** on the **App Store** at this time.

**Gemini** also became one of the **top five iPhone apps overall** in **108 countries globally**, **Appfigures‚Äô data** indicates.

On **Google Play**, **Gemini** jumped from the **No. 26 overall top app** in the **U.S.** on **September 8** to become the **No. 2 app** as of Monday. However, despite **Android** being **Google‚Äôs own platform**, **ChatGPT** remains in the **top spot** as of the time of writing.

## üì¢ **Google‚Äôs Promotion and User Engagement**

**Google** has been **touting Gemini‚Äôs growth**, as more **mainstream users** have been trying out the **new image-editing features**. For instance, **Google Gemini and Google Labs VP Josh Woodward** shared on **X** on **September 8** that the app had gained **23 million first-time users** since the **Nano Banana model** launched, and those users had shared over **500 million images**.

## üí∞ **Increased Consumer Spending**

The app‚Äôs **rapid growth** is also driving **increases in consumer spending**.

Of the **$6.3 million** **Gemini** generated this year on **iOS devices**, **$1.6 million** was from the month of **August**, with much of that coming in after the **Nano Banana model‚Äôs release**. That‚Äôs up **1,291%** from **January‚Äôs figure** of **$115,000**, **Appfigures estimates**.

The app is also on track to at least **match August‚Äôs number** if not **surpass it** in **September**, as **Gemini** has pulled in **$792,000** so far this month ‚Äî roughly half of **August‚Äôs total**.

This year, **Gemini‚Äôs app** has been downloaded **103.7 million times** and has seen **185.4 million downloads** to date since its launch on **Android** in **February 2024** and its expansion to **iOS** later that year.

---

title: The 9 most sought-after startups from YC Demo Day
content:
### R√©sum√©
Y Combinator a organis√© son Demo Day d'√©t√© 2025, pr√©sentant plus de 160 startups, dont la majorit√© propose des solutions centr√©es sur l'IA. Une √©volution notable est la transition vers des agents IA ou les infrastructures n√©cessaires √† leur d√©veloppement. Plusieurs startups ont retenu l'attention des investisseurs, notamment Autumn (billing pour startups IA), Dedalus Labs (infrastructure pour agents IA), Design Arena (crowdsourcing de designs), Getasap Asia (distribution tech-enablee), Keystone (r√©paration de bugs), RealRoots (matchmaking amical), Solva (automatisation de claims d'assurance), Perseus (contre-drones), et Pingo (tuteur de langues).

## üöÄ **Y Combinator Summer 2025 Demo Day: Highlights and Standout Startups**

Y Combinator hosted its **Summer 2025 Demo Day** last week, showcasing the latest batch of over **160 startups**. As with recent batches, the majority of startups presented **AI-centric solutions**. However, a clear evolution was evident. Instead of ‚ÄúAI-powered‚Äù products, many companies are now building **AI agents** or the **infrastructure and tools** needed to develop them. For instance, this batch had a flurry of **voice AI solutions** and new businesses focused on helping others monetize the **‚ÄúAI economy‚Äù** with ads and marketing tools.

We spoke with a handful of **YC-focused investors** to learn which startups they found most interesting and which generated the highest investment demand.

Below are the most frequently mentioned ones:

### üèÜ **Top Startups**

#### **Autumn**
- **What it does**: **Stripe for AI startups**
- **Why it‚Äôs a fave**: Many **AI startups** use complex pricing models that often blend a flat subscription fee per seat with usage-based charges, credits, and various add-on costs. Managing complex AI pricing on **Stripe** is a time-consuming, manual process. That‚Äôs why **Autumn** developed an **open-source infrastructure** that simplifies **Stripe integration** for AI startups. The company says its technology is already used by hundreds of AI apps and 40 YC startups. Given **Stripe‚Äôs dominance** in payments and the explosive growth of the **AI market**, could a specialized billing solution for AI be the next major **fintech success story**?

#### **Dedalus Labs**
- **What it does**: **Builds Vercel for AI agents**
- **Why it‚Äôs a fave**: Just as **Vercel** helps developers deploy and host startups, **Dedalus Labs** claims its platform automates the infrastructure for building **AI agents**, cutting hours of coding down to a few clicks. The company handles complex tasks like autoscaling and load balancing, which it says makes agent deployment fast and simple.

#### **Design Arena**
- **What it does**: **Crowdsources rankings of vibe-coded designs**
- **Why it‚Äôs a fave**: The ability of AI to rapidly generate a huge number of designs creates a new problem: figuring out which ones are actually good. **Design Arena** solves this by crowdsourcing rankings of AI-generated visuals, creating a feedback loop that forces AI models to improve. Large AI labs see value in training their models to generate better designs, as some of them are already **Design Arena‚Äôs customers**.

#### **Getasap Asia**
- **What it does**: **Tech-enabled distributor for retailers in Southeast Asia**
- **Why it‚Äôs a fave**: **Getasap Asia** was founded by **Raghav Arora** three years ago when he was just 14 years old. Since then, the startup that uses tech to deliver supplies to corner stores, restaurants, and large supermarkets in **Southeast Asia** in under eight hours, has earned millions in revenue. **Getasap Asia** closed a round from **General Catalyst**, according to its website, and we are hearing that the startup‚Äôs valuation was among the highest in the whole batch.

#### **Keystone**
- **What it does**: **AI engineer that fixes bugs in production**
- **Why it‚Äôs a fave**: Founded by a 20-year-old **Pablo Hansen** who last year earned a master‚Äôs degree in AI, **Keystone** is on a mission to reduce software breaks. The company‚Äôs AI finds and fixes bugs for clients like **Lovable** and has already turned down a seven-figure acquisition offer, Hansen said.

#### **RealRoots**
- **What it does**: **AI matchmaker for female friends**
- **Why it‚Äôs a fave**: While there isn‚Äôt a shortage of dating apps, **RealRoots** is tackling a different kind of loneliness. The company‚Äôs AI matchmaker, **Lisa**, interviews women and then organizes social experiences to connect them with compatible friends. While the AI part might be performative ‚Äì conversations with Lisa probably wouldn‚Äôt give **RealRoots** more insights about participants than written answers would ‚Äì **RealRoots** may be on to something. Last month alone, the company generated **$782,000** from 9,000 paying clients, its founders said.

#### **Solva**
- **What it does**: **Automates insurance claims with AI**
- **Why it‚Äôs a fave**: **Solva‚Äôs AI** automates the most routine tasks for insurance adjusters, from filling out complex claims to preventing improper payouts. Just ten weeks after launching, **Solva** has already amassed **$245,000** in annual recurring revenue (ARR), a figure that has investors excited.

#### **Perseus**
- **What it does**: **Counter-drone mini-missiles**
- **Why it‚Äôs a fave**: With **China** reportedly amassing swarms of inexpensive drones, the U.S. military faces an urgent need for cost-effective counter-drone solutions. **Perseus** is developing just that: small missiles designed to shoot down drones at a fraction of the cost of existing systems. Multiple branches of the U.S. military have already invited the startup to demonstrate its solution, which could lead to hefty contracts.

#### **Pingo**
- **What it does**: **AI foreign language tutor**
- **Why it‚Äôs a fave**: Apps like **Duolingo** have made language learning accessible and fun, but they often lack a key component of fluency: consistent conversation. **Pingo** solves this problem by allowing users to speak with its AI, which acts as a native speaker. The company‚Äôs unique approach is proving incredibly popular, with founders claiming it‚Äôs growing 70% monthly and earning **$250,000** in monthly revenue.

title: Apple‚Äôs iOS 26 with the new Liquid Glass design is now available to everyone
content:
Apple‚Äôs iOS 26 software update for iPhones is available Monday to people who have an iPhone 11, iPhone SE 2, and later. The marquee feature of iOS 26 is Apple‚Äôs Liquid Glass design, which includes elements on-screen that resembled a ‚Äúglassy‚Äù look. Other features include a call screening assistant, a new gaming and preview app, in-app translation across the system, and updates to Genmoji and Image Playground apps.
The operating system update also went through a big numerical change as Apple jumped from iOS 18 to iOS 26 for two key reasons. First, it wanted to bring all operating systems ‚Äî iOS, iPadOS, macOS, watchOS, tvOS, and VisionOS ‚Äî in sync. And it also wanted to reflect the year number in which the majority of the people will use this update.
Liquid Glass design has been the most significant visual overhaul for iOS in years. Apple‚Äôs intention with this redesign was to take inspiration from the Vision Pro interface and apply it to all of its operating systems. The elements are meant to look like they are made of translucent glass. This resulted in challenges in terms of readability and how elements in the background look.
Since June, Apple has made several changes to how ‚Äúglassy‚Äù the interface looks through beta releases. While the company is releasing the stable version of iOS 26 today, we might expect visual tweaks for improved readability and usability in the coming months. This visual change might take a bit of time for users to adjust, and they might not like certain elements right away.
The Phone app has a new unified look where your favorites are up top in a card format with recents and voicemails on the same screen. You can tap the filter button on the top right and look at these sections individually as well. (If you don‚Äôt like the new interface, Apple also gives you an option to switch to the classic look.)
In addition, iOS 26 brings a call-screening feature to iPhones, which is a personal favorite. When an unknown number calls you, the system asks for their name and the purpose of the call. Once they give this information, the system invokes the ringer and notifies you of the call. You can look at the conversation and interject at any time. Transcription of voicemail doesn‚Äôt work well for all languages, but call screening has reduced the number of calls I‚Äôve had to pick up.
There‚Äôs also a holding assist for when a restaurant or a helpline places you on hold; you can use call assist to notify when an agent starts talking again.
The Messages app is getting to feature party with other chat apps like WhatsApp and Telegram with backgrounds, new conversation flow, polls, text selection, photo previews, and typing indicators in groups. Apple has been working on SMS filtering for a few years now. The company said it updated its spam filtering with this release. Plus, it places messages from unknown senders in a new folder. One thing I didn‚Äôt like about this update is that it takes me a couple of taps to go to the transactions tab.
The games app overhaul means that you can look at the games you are playing (or have played), arcade games, challenges, and achievements in one place, along with suggestions for new titles. The app also shows you what your friends are playing.
Apple finally added Mac‚Äôs Preview app to iOS 26, which means you can edit, annotate, and sign PDFs more easily.
Meanwhile, Apple Music now has automixing for dynamic song switching, along with lyrics translation and pronunciation. What‚Äôs more, you can pin your favorite songs and playlists.
With iOS 26, Apple Maps lets you define preferred routes while commuting. In case your choice of route has more traffic or any incidents, Maps sends you a notification along with suggesting alternative routes. The app also lets you easily view visited places through a new places library.
The Camera app in iOS 26 adopts the Liquid Glass design with only Video and Photo options visible by default. You can scroll to the left or right to switch between different modes. Apple has placed some controls like Flash and Night mode on the top right, and you can switch them on/off with one touch. For more options like filters, styles, exposure controls, and timer, you can swipe up from the bottom of the screen.
If you didn‚Äôt like the previous Photos app design, the tabs are back in this version.
Unlike last year‚Äôs grand launch of Apple Intelligence, this year‚Äôs operating system is light on AI features, especially given delays in launching and rolling out features. The company is making AI-powered translation easily available in apps like Messages, FaceTime, and Phone. Currently, this feature supports English (U.K., U.S.), French (France), German, Portuguese (Brazil), and Spanish (Spain).
Through iOS 26, the company is also launching live translation on AirPods, including the newly launched AirPods Pro 3, AirPods Pro 2, and AirPods 4.
Also, iOS 26 updates visual intelligence to understand the content on the screen. You have to press Power + the volume down button to bring up this menu. Apple Intelligence can then suggest events to add to your calendar. You can also ask questions about the content on the screen, using Google Visual Search or ChatGPT. Apple is also releasing its own ‚ÄúCircle to search‚Äù called Highlight.
The most confusing part about this update is that the buttons used to bring up on-screen visual intelligence are the same as the screenshot button. Because of this, it takes an extra step to save a screenshot, and I have forgotten to save some important screenshots.
Apple is updating Genmoji with iOS 26 to let you merge two emojis with a text prompt and make something new. You can now add expression to people in both Genmoji and Image Playground. Update to Image Playground now allows you to modify attributes like hair and facial hair, along with new styles from ChatGPT.
We have a list of tons of small but useful iOS features here. You can update to iOS 26 by going to Settings > General > Software Update and downloading the latest version.
¬© 2025 TechCrunch Media LLC.

title: OpenAI upgrades Codex with a new version of GPT-5
content:
OpenAI announced Monday that it‚Äôs releasing a new version of GPT-5 to its AI coding agent, Codex. The company says its new model, called GPT-5-Codex, spends its ‚Äúthinking‚Äù time more dynamically than previous models and could spend anywhere from a few seconds to seven hours on a coding task. As a result, it performs better on agentic coding benchmarks.
The new model is now rolling out in Codex products ‚Äî which can be accessed via a terminal, IDE, GitHub, or ChatGPT ‚Äî to all ChatGPT Plus, Pro, Business, Edu, and Enterprise users. OpenAI says it plans to make the model available to API customers in the future.
The update is part of OpenAI‚Äôs effort to make Codex more competitive with other AI coding products, such as Claude Code, Anysphere‚Äôs Cursor, or Microsoft‚Äôs GitHub Copilot. The market for AI coding tools has become much more crowded in the last year as a result of intense user demand. Cursor surpassed $500 million in ARR earlier in 2025, and Windsurf, a similar code editor, was the subject of a chaotic acquisition attempt that saw its team split between Google and Cognition.
OpenAI says that GPT-5-Codex outperforms GPT-5 on SWE-bench Verified, a benchmark measuring agentic coding abilities, as well as a benchmark measuring performance on code refactoring tasks from large, established repositories.
The company also says it trained GPT-5-Codex for conducting code reviews and asked experience software engineers to evaluate the model‚Äôs review comments. The engineers reportedly found GPT-5-Codex to submit fewer incorrect comments, while adding more ‚Äúhigh-impact comments.‚Äù
In a briefing, OpenAI‚Äôs Codex product lead Alexander Embiricos said that much of the increased performance was thanks to GPT-5-Codex‚Äôs dynamic ‚Äúthinking abilities.‚Äù Users may be familiar with GPT-5‚Äôs router in ChatGPT, which directs queries to different models based on the complexity of a task. Embiricos said GPT-5-Codex works similarly but has no router under the hood and can adjust for how long to work on a task in real time.
Embiricos says this is an advantage compared to a router, which decides how much computational power and time to use on a problem at the outset. Instead, GPT-5-Codex can decide five minutes into a problem that it needs to spend another hour. Embiricos said he‚Äôs seen the model take upward of seven hours in some cases.
¬© 2025 TechCrunch Media LLC.

title: Spotify will now let free users pick and play tracks
content:
Following its long-awaited launch of lossless streaming for paid subscribers, Spotify is upgrading its service for free users, too. On Monday, the company announced that free users globally will now be able to search and play any song they want or play a song shared by a friend or an artist they follow on social media.
The company calls the new features ‚ÄúPick & Play,‚Äù ‚ÄúSearch & Play,‚Äù and ‚ÄúShare & Play,‚Äù respectively. With the former, free users can hit play in the Spotify app to pick and play any song they want, or can even search for a particular song and play it.
The ‚ÄúShare & Play‚Äù feature could encourage free users to open Spotify when they come across music on social media. For instance, Instagram lets users share a Spotify track to Stories with sound and allows users to share music on Instagram Notes.
Previously, free users could shuffle songs with limited skips on mobile devices.
Spotify says the new features will roll out globally to free users, but there will still be some restrictions that Premium users won‚Äôt face.
When reached for clarification, the company told TechCrunch that users on the free mobile experience will have an allocation of ‚Äúon-demand time,‚Äù and when they reach that daily limit, they‚Äôll then be restricted to a limited number of skips per hour. Spotify did not share what that time limit is, but noted that Premium users will not have these restrictions.
In recent months, Spotify‚Äôs ad business has been struggling, with CEO Daniel Ek telling investors the company has been ‚Äúmoving too slowly‚Äù on this front. The streamer wants ad revenue to make up 20% of its overall revenue, but has grown it only to 11% as of June. By adding new free features, Spotify could boost engagement among its free user base, who would then be exposed to more ads.
Spotify says that other features, like its support for¬†lossless, AI Playlists, and Mix, will remain Premium-only offerings, while others like the newly launched Messages and personalized playlist daylist, available to global users, will span both the free and paid experiences, as they had before.
The company‚Äôs free users today make up the bulk of its user base. Out of Spotify‚Äôs 696 million monthly active users in the most recent quarter, 433 million were free, ad-supported customers. In addition, there were 276 million Premium (paying) subscribers in the quarter.
Updated after publication with more information about the restrictions impacting free users.
¬© 2025 TechCrunch Media LLC.

title: Vibe coding has turned senior devs into ‚ÄòAI babysitters,‚Äô but they say it‚Äôs worth it
content:
Carla Rover once spent 30 minutes sobbing after having to restart a project she vibe coded.
Rover has been in the industry for 15 years, mainly working as a web developer. She‚Äôs now building a startup, alongside her son, that creates custom machine learning models for marketplaces.
She called vibe coding a beautiful, endless cocktail napkin on which one can perpetually sketch ideas. But dealing with AI-generated code that one hopes to use in production can be ‚Äúworse than babysitting,‚Äù she said, as these AI models can mess up work in ways that are hard to predict.
She had turned to AI coding in a need for speed with her startup, as is the promise of AI tools.
‚ÄúBecause I needed to be quick and impressive, I took a shortcut and did not scan those files after the automated review,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWhen I did do it manually, I found so much wrong. When I used a third-party tool, I found more. And I learned my lesson.‚Äù
She and her son wound up restarting their whole project ‚Äî hence the tears. ‚ÄúI handed it off like the copilot was an employee,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt.‚Äù
Rover is like many experienced programmers turning to AI for coding help. But such programmers are also finding themselves acting like AI babysitters ‚Äî rewriting and fact-checking the code the AI spits out.
A recent report by content delivery platform company Fastly found that at least 95% of the nearly 800 developers it surveyed said they spend extra time fixing AI-generated code, with the load of such verification falling most heavily on the shoulders of senior developers.
These experienced coders have discovered issues with AI-generated code ranging from hallucinating package names to deleting important information and security risks. Left unchecked, AI code can leave a product far more buggy than what humans would produce.
Working with AI-generated code has become such a problem that it‚Äôs given rise to a new corporate coding job known as ‚Äúvibe code cleanup specialist.‚Äù
TechCrunch spoke to experienced coders about their time using AI-generated code about what they see as the future of vibe coding. Thoughts varied, but one thing remained certain: The technology still has a long way to go.
‚ÄúUsing a coding co-pilot is kind of like giving a coffee pot to a smart six-year-old and saying, ‚ÄòPlease take this into the dining room and pour coffee for the family,‚Äô‚Äù Rover said.
Can they do it? Possibly. Could they fail? Definitely. And most likely, if they do fail, they aren‚Äôt going to tell you. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt make the kid less clever,‚Äù she continued. ‚ÄúIt just means you can‚Äôt delegate [a task] like that completely.‚Äù
Feridoon Malekzadeh also compared vibe coding to a child.
He‚Äôs worked in the industry for more than 20 years, holding various roles in product development, software, and design. He‚Äôs building his own startup and heavily using vibe-coding platform Lovable, he said. For fun, he also vibe codes apps like one that generates Gen Alpha slang for Boomers.
He likes that he‚Äôs able to work alone on projects, saving time and money, but agrees that vibe coding is not like hiring an intern or a junior coder. Instead, vibe coding is akin to ‚Äúhiring your stubborn, insolent teenager to help you do something,‚Äù he told TechCrunch.
‚ÄúYou have to ask them 15 times to do something,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIn the end, they do some of what you asked, some stuff you didn‚Äôt ask for, and they break a bunch of things along the way.‚Äù
Malekzadeh estimates he spends around 50% of his time writing requirements, 10% to 20% of his time on vibe coding, and 30% to 40% of his time on vibe fixing ‚Äî remedying the bugs and ‚Äúunnecessary script‚Äù created by AI-written code.
He also doesn‚Äôt think vibe coding is the best at systems thinking ‚Äî the process of seeing how a complex problem could impact an overall result. AI-generated code, he said, tries to solve more surface-level problems.
‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre creating a feature that should be broadly available in your product, a good engineer would create that once and make it available everywhere that it‚Äôs needed,‚Äù Malekzadeh said. ‚ÄúVibe coding will create something five different times, five different ways, if it‚Äôs needed in five different places. It leads to a lot of confusion, not only for the user, but for the model.‚Äù
Meanwhile, Rover finds that AI ‚Äúruns into a wall‚Äù when data conflicts with what it was hard-coded to do. ‚ÄúIt can offer misleading advice, leave out key elements that are vital, or insert itself into a thought pathway you‚Äôre developing,‚Äù she said.
She also found that rather than admit to making errors, it will manufacture results.
She shared another example with TechCrunch, where she questioned the results an AI model initially gave her. The model started to give a detailed explanation pretending it used the data she uploaded. Only when she called it out did the AI model confess.
‚ÄúIt freaked me out because it sounded like a toxic co-worker,‚Äù she said.
On top of this, there are the security concerns.
Austin Spires is the senior director of developer enablement at Fastly and has been coding since the early 2000s.
He‚Äôs found through his own experience ‚Äî along with chatting with customers ‚Äî that vibe code likes to build what is quick rather than what is ‚Äúright.‚Äù This may introduce vulnerabilities to the code of the kind that very new programmers tend to make, he said.
‚ÄúWhat often happens is the engineer needs to review the code, correct the agent, and tell the agent that they made a mistake,‚Äù Spires told TechCrunch. ‚ÄúThis pattern is why we‚Äôve seen the trope of ‚Äòyou‚Äôre absolutely right‚Äô appear over social media.‚Äù
He‚Äôs referring to how AI models, like Anthropic Claude, tend to respond ‚Äúyou‚Äôre absolutely right‚Äù when called out on their mistakes.
Mike Arrowsmith, the chief trust officer at the IT management software company NinjaOne, has been in software engineering and security for around 20 years. He said that vibe coding is creating a new generation of IT and security blind spots to which young startups in particular are susceptible.
‚ÄúVibe coding often bypasses the rigorous review processes that are foundational to traditional coding and crucial to catching vulnerabilities,‚Äù he told TechCrunch.
NinjaOne, he said, counters this by encouraging ‚Äúsafe vibe coding,‚Äù where approved AI tools have access controls, along with mandatory peer review and, of course, security scanning.
While nearly everyone we spoke to agrees that AI-generated code and vibe-coding platforms are useful in many situations ‚Äî like mocking up ideas ‚Äî they all agree that human review is essential before building a business on it.
‚ÄúThat cocktail napkin is not a business model,‚Äù Rover said. ‚ÄúYou have to balance the ease with insight.‚Äù
But for all the lamenting on its errors, vibe coding has changed the present and the future of the job.
Rover said vibe coding helped her tremendously in crafting a better user interface. Malekzadeh simply said that, despite the time he spends fixing code, he still gets more done with AI coders than without them.
‚Äú‚ÄòEvery technology carries its own negativity, which is invented at the same time as technical progress,‚Äù Malekzadeh said, quoting the French theorist Paul Virilio, who spoke about inventing the shipwreck along with the ship.
The Fastly survey found that senior developers were twice as likely to put AI-generated code into production compared to junior developers, saying that the technology helped them work faster.
Vibe coding is also part of Spires‚Äô coding routine. He uses AI coding agents on several platforms for both front-end and back-end personal projects. He called the technology a mixed experience but said it‚Äôs good in helping with prototyping, building out boilerplate, or scaffolding out a test; it removes menial tasks so that engineers can focus on building, shipping, and scaling products.
It seems the extra hours spent combing through the vibe weeds will simply become a tolerated tax on using the innovation.
Elvis Kimara, a young engineer, is learning that now. He just graduated with a master‚Äôs in AI and is building an AI-powered marketplace.
Like many coders, he said vibe coding has made his job harder and has often found vibe coding a joyless experience.
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no more dopamine from solving a problem by myself. The AI just figures it out,‚Äù he said. At one of his last jobs, he said senior developers didn‚Äôt look to help young coders as much¬†‚Äî some not understanding new vibe-coding models, while others delegated mentorship tasks to said AI models.
But, he said, ‚Äúthe pros far outweigh the cons,‚Äù and he‚Äôs prepared to pay the innovation tax.
‚ÄúWe won‚Äôt just be writing code; we‚Äôll be guiding AI systems, taking accountability when things break, and acting more like consultants to machines,‚Äù Kimara said of the new normal for which he‚Äôs preparing.
‚ÄúEven as I grow into a senior role, I‚Äôll keep using it,‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a real accelerator for me. I make sure I review every line of AI-generated code so I learn even faster from it.‚Äù
This post was updated to reflect the proper title of Mike Arrowsmith.

title: ‚ÄòSelling coffee beans to Starbucks‚Äô ‚Äî how the AI boom could leave AI‚Äôs biggest companies behind
content:
How much do foundation models matter?
It might seem like a silly question, but it‚Äôs come up a lot in my conversations with AI startups, which are increasingly comfortable with businesses that used to be dismissed as ‚ÄúGPT wrappers,‚Äù or companies that build interfaces on top of existing AI models like ChatGPT.
These days, startup teams are focused on customizing AI models for specific tasks and interface work, and see the foundation model as a commodity that can be swapped in and out as necessary. That approach was on display especially at last week‚Äôs BoxWorks conference, which seemed devoted entirely to the user-facing software built on top of AI models.
Part of what is driving this is that the scaling benefits of pre-training ‚Äî that initial process of teaching AI models using massive datasets, which is the sole domain of foundation models ‚Äî has slowed down. That doesn‚Äôt mean AI has stopped making progress, but the early benefits of hyperscaled foundational models have hit diminishing returns, and attention has turned to post-training and reinforcement learning as sources of future progress.
If you want to make a better AI coding tool, you‚Äôre better off working on fine-tuning and interface design rather than spending another few billion dollars‚Äô worth in server time on pre-training. As the success of Anthropic‚Äôs Claude Code shows, foundation model companies are quite good at these other fields too ‚Äî but it‚Äôs not as durable an advantage as it used to be.
In short, the competitive landscape of AI is changing in ways that undermine the advantages of the biggest AI labs. Instead of a race for an all-powerful AGI that could match or exceed human abilities across all cognitive tasks, the immediate future looks like a flurry of discrete businesses: software development, enterprise data management, image generation, and so on.
Aside from a first-mover advantage, it‚Äôs not clear that building a foundation model gives you any advantage in those businesses. Worse, the abundance of open source alternatives means that foundation models may not have any price leverage if they lose the competition at the application layer. This would turn companies like OpenAI and Anthropic into back-end suppliers in a low-margin commodity business ‚Äî as one founder put it to me, ‚Äúlike selling coffee beans to Starbucks.‚Äù
It‚Äôs hard to overstate what a dramatic shift this would be for the business of AI. Throughout the contemporary boom, the success of AI has been inextricable from the success of the companies building foundation models ‚Äî specifically, OpenAI, Anthropic, and Google. Being bullish on AI meant believing that AI‚Äôs transformative impact would make these into generationally important companies. We could argue about which company would come out on top, but it was clear that some foundation model company was going to end up with the keys to the kingdom.
At the time, there were lots of reasons to think this was true. For years, foundation model development was the only AI business there was ‚Äî and the fast pace of progress made their lead seem insurmountable. And Silicon Valley has always had a deep-rooted love of platform advantage. The assumption was that, however AI models ended up making money, the lion‚Äôs share of the benefit would flow back to the foundation model companies, which had done the work that was hardest to replicate.
The past year has made that story more complicated. There are lots of successful third-party AI services, but they tend to use foundation models interchangeably. For startups, it no longer matters whether their product sits on top of GPT-5, Claude, or Gemini, and they expect to be able to switch models in mid-release without end users noticing the difference. Foundation models continue to make real progress, but it no longer seems plausible for any one company to maintain a large enough advantage to dominate the industry.
We already have plenty of indication that there is not much of a first-mover advantage. As venture capitalist Martin Casado of a16z pointed out on a recent podcast, OpenAI was the first lab to put out a coding model, as well as generative models for image and video ‚Äî only to lose all three categories to competitors. ‚ÄúAs far as we can tell, there is no inherent moat in the technology stack for AI,‚Äù Casado concluded.
Of course, we shouldn‚Äôt count foundation model companies out just yet. There are still lots of durable advantages on their side, including brand recognition, infrastructure, and unthinkably vast cash reserves. OpenAI‚Äôs consumer business may prove harder to replicate than its coding business, and other advantages may emerge as the sector matures. Given the fast pace of AI development, the current interest in post-training could easily reverse course in the next six months. Most uncertain of all, the race toward general intelligence could pay off with new breakthroughs in pharmaceuticals or materials science, radically shifting our ideas about what makes AI models valuable.
But in the meantime, the strategy of building ever-bigger foundation models looks a lot less appealing than it did last year ‚Äî and Meta‚Äôs billion-dollar spending spree is starting to look awfully risky.

title: Why California‚Äôs SB 53 might provide a meaningful check on big AI companies
content:
California‚Äôs state senate recently gave final approval to a new AI safety bill, SB 53, sending it to Governor Gavin Newsom to either sign or veto.
If this all sounds familiar, that‚Äôs because Newsom vetoed another AI safety bill, also written by state senator Scott Wiener, last year. But SB 53 is narrower than Wiener‚Äôs previous SB 1047, with a focus on big AI companies making more than $500 million in annual revenue.
I got the chance to discuss SB 53 with my colleagues Max Zeff and Kirsten Korosec on the latest episode of TechCrunch‚Äôs flagship podcast Equity. Max believes that Wiener‚Äôs new bill has a better shot of becoming law, partly because of that big company focus, and because it‚Äôs been endorsed by AI company Anthropic.
Read a preview of our conversation about AI safety and state-level legislation below. (I‚Äôve edited the transcript for length and clarity, and to make us sound slightly smarter.)
Max: Why should you care about AI safety legislation that‚Äôs passing a chamber in California? We‚Äôre entering this era where AI companies are becoming the most powerful companies in the world, and this is going to be potentially one of the few checks on their power.
This is much narrower than SB 1047, which got a lot of pushback last year. But I think SB 53 still puts some meaningful regulations on the AI labs. It makes them publish safety reports for their models. If they have an incident, it basically forces them to report that to the government. And it also, for employees at these labs, if they have concerns, gives them a channel to report that to the government and not face pushback from the companies, even though a lot of them have signed NDAs.
To me, this feels like a potentially meaningful check on tech companies‚Äô power, something we haven‚Äôt really had for the last couple of decades.
Kirsten: To your point about why it matters at the state level, it‚Äôs important to think about the fact that it‚Äôs California. Every major AI company is pretty much, if not based here, it has a major footprint in this state. Not that other states don‚Äôt matter ‚Äî I do not want to be getting emails from the folks in Colorado or whatever ‚Äî¬† but it does matter that it‚Äôs specifically California because it‚Äôs really a hub of AI activity.
My question for you, though, Max, is it just seems like there‚Äôs a lot of exceptions and carve-outs. It‚Äôs narrower, but is it more complicated than the previous [bill]?
Max: In some ways, yes. I would say the main carve-out of this bill is that it really tries to not apply to small startups. And basically, one of the main controversies around the last legislative effort from Senator Scott Weiner, who represents San Francisco, who authored this bill, a lot of people said it could harm the startup ecosystem, which a lot of people take issue with because that‚Äôs such a booming part of California‚Äôs economy right now.
This bill specifically applies to AI developers that are [generating] more than $500 million [from] their AI models. This really tries to target OpenAI, Google DeepMind, these big companies and not your run-of-the-mill startup.
Anthony: As I understand it, if you‚Äôre a smaller startup, you do have to share some safety information, but not nearly as much.
It‚Äôs [also] worth talking about the broader landscape around AI regulation and the fact that one of the big changes between last year and this year is now we have a new president. The federal administration has taken much more of a stance of no regulation and companies should be able to do what they want, to the extent that they‚Äôve actually included [language] in funding bills saying states cannot have their own AI regulation.
I don‚Äôt think any of that has passed so far, but potentially they could try to get that through in the future. So this could be another front in which the Trump administration and blue states are fighting.
Equity is TechCrunch‚Äôs flagship podcast, produced by Theresa Loconsolo, and posts every Wednesday and Friday.

title: Octopus Energy spins off its Kraken utility billing and AI platform
content:
British renewable energy provider Octopus Energy said this week that it‚Äôs spinning off Kraken, its tech platform for utilities, spurred in part by $500 million in committed annual revenue from other utilities and energy providers.
An eventual Kraken IPO could be valued at $15 billion and could occur within a year, according to The Wall Street Journal.
Kraken was actually the company‚Äôs initial product, per Octopus CEO Greg Jackson. ‚ÄúWe created Octopus as the ‚Äòdemo client,‚Äô‚Äù he told the Journal earlier this year. That demo client has since grown to provide power to more than 7.7 million households in the U.K. and another 2.8 million elsewhere.
The spinoff would help Kraken minimize conflicts of interest as it signs deals with utilities and power providers that aren‚Äôt Octopus, the company said. Octopus originally set the spinoff in motion last year.
Octopus was founded in 2015, and within a decade became the U.K.‚Äôs largest energy provider, overtaking British Gas, which was founded more than 200 years ago.
Part of that growth has stemmed from creative marketing and customer-acquisition strategies.
One, called Zero Bills, allowed homeowners to eliminate their energy bills for a decade if they bought properties that were entirely electrified. Another, a tariff it calls Agile, encourages customers to shift their electricity use to times when there‚Äôs a surplus on the grid. In some cases, consumers can run loads of laundry for free.
As Octopus gathered data from those projects, it used AI models built into Kraken to sift through it to determine how increasing amounts of renewable energy can work on the grid.
For utilities and power providers, Kraken allows them to call on power sources when needed, including renewables, solar, and so-called distributed energy resources, which include EV chargers, smart thermostats, and home batteries. It has also built a customer management system that covers everything from billing, meter management, and customer relations.
¬© 2025 TechCrunch Media LLC.

title: How developers are using Apple‚Äôs local AI models with iOS 26
content:
Earlier this year, Apple introduced its Foundation Models framework during WWDC 2025, which allows developers to use the company‚Äôs local AI models to power features in their applications.
The company touted that with this framework, developers gain access to AI models without worrying about any inference cost. Plus, these local models have capabilities such as guided generation and tool calling built in.
As iOS 26 is rolling out to all users, developers have been updating their apps to include features powered by Apple‚Äôs local AI models. Apple‚Äôs models are small compared with leading models from OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, or Meta. That is why local-only features largely improve quality of life with these apps rather than introducing major changes to the app‚Äôs workflow.
Below are some of the first apps to tap into Apple‚Äôs AI framework.
The Lil Artist app offers various interactive experiences to help kids learn different skills like creativity, math, and music. Developer Arima Jain shipped an AI story creator with the iOS 26 update. This allows users to select a character and a theme, with the app generating a story using AI. The developer said that the text generation in the story is powered by the local model.
The developer of the Daylish app is working on a prototype for automatically suggesting emojis for timeline events based on the title for the daily planner app.
Finance tracking app MoneyCoach has two neat features powered by local models. First, the app shows insights about your spending, such as whether you spent more than average on groceries for that particular week. The other feature automatically suggests categories and subcategories for a spending item for quick entries.
The word learning app LookUp has added two new modes using Apple‚Äôs AI models. There is a new learning mode, which leverages a local model to create examples corresponding to a word. Plus, the example asks users to explain the usage of the word in a sentence.
The developer is also using on-device models to generate a map view of a word‚Äôs origin.
Just like a few other apps, the Tasks app implemented a feature to suggest tags for an entry using local models automatically. It‚Äôs also using these models to detect a recurring task and schedule it accordingly. And the app lets users speak a few things and use the local model to break them down into various tasks without using the internet.
Automattic-owned journaling app Day One is using Apple‚Äôs models to get highlights and suggest titles for your entry. The team has also implemented a feature to generate prompts that nudge you to dive deeper and write more based on what you have already written.
Recipe app Crouton is using Apple Intelligence to suggest tags for a recipe and assign names to timers. It also uses AI to break down a block of text into easy-to-follow steps for cooking.
Digital signing app SignEasy is using Apple‚Äôs local models to extract key insights from a contract and give users a summary of the document they are signing.
We will continue updating this list as we discover more apps using Apple‚Äôs local models.

title: Meta CTO explains why the smart glasses demos failed at Meta Connect ‚Äî and it wasn‚Äôt the Wi-Fi
content:
Meta chief technology officer Andrew Bosworth took to his Instagram to explain, in more technical detail, why multiple demos of Meta‚Äôs new smart glasses technology failed at Meta Connect, the company‚Äôs developer conference, this week.
Meta on Wednesday introduced three new pairs of smart glasses, including an upgraded version of its existing Ray-Ban Meta, a new Meta Ray-Ban Display that comes with a wristband controller, and the sports-focused Oakley Meta Vanguard.
However, at different points during the event, the live technology demos failed to work.
In one, cooking content creator Jack Mancuso asked his Ray-Ban Meta glasses how to get started with a particular sauce recipe. After repeating the question, ‚ÄúWhat do I do first?‚Äù with no response, the AI skipped ahead in the recipe, forcing him to stop the demo. He then tossed it back to Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg, saying that he thinks the Wi-Fi may be messed up.
In another demo, the glasses failed to pick up a live WhatsApp video call between Bosworth and Zuckerberg; Zuckerberg eventually had to give up. Bosworth walked onstage, joking about the ‚Äúbrutal‚Äù Wi-Fi.
‚ÄúYou practice these things like a hundred times, and then you never know what‚Äôs gonna happen,‚Äù Zuckerberg said at the time.
After the event, Bosworth took to his Instagram for a Q&A session about the new tech and the live demo failures.
On the latter, he explained that it wasn‚Äôt actually the Wi-Fi that caused the issue with the chef‚Äôs glasses. Instead, it was a mistake in resource management planning.
‚ÄúWhen the chef said, ‚ÄòHey, Meta, start Live AI,‚Äô it started every single Ray-Ban Meta‚Äôs Live AI in the building. And there were a lot of people in that building,‚Äù Bosworth explained. ‚ÄúThat obviously didn‚Äôt happen in rehearsal; we didn‚Äôt have as many things,‚Äù he said, referring to the number of glasses that were triggered.
That alone wasn‚Äôt enough to cause the disruption, though. The second part of the failure had to do with how Meta had chosen to route the Live AI traffic to its development server to isolate it during the demo. But when it did so, it did this for everyone in the building on the access points, which included all the headsets.
‚ÄúSo we DDoS‚Äôd ourselves, basically, with that demo,‚Äù Bosworth added. (A DDoS attack, or a distributed denial of service attack, is one where a flood of traffic overwhelms a server or service, slowing it down or making it unavailable. In this case, Meta‚Äôs dev server wasn‚Äôt set up to handle the flood of traffic from the other glasses in the building ‚Äî Meta was only planning for it to handle the demos alone.)
The issue with the failed WhatsApp call, on the other hand, was the result of a new bug.
The smart glasses‚Äô display had gone to sleep at the exact moment the call came in, Bosworth said. When Zuckerberg woke the display back up, it didn‚Äôt show the answer notification to him. The CTO said this was a ‚Äúrace condition‚Äù bug, or where the outcome depends on the unpredictable and uncoordinated timing of two or more different processes trying to use the same resource simultaneously.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôve never run into that bug before,‚Äù Bosworth noted. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the first time we‚Äôd ever seen it. It‚Äôs fixed now, and that‚Äôs a terrible, terrible place for that bug to show up.‚Äù He stressed that, of course, Meta knows how to handle video calls, and the company was ‚Äúbummed‚Äù about the bug showing up here.
Despite the issues, Bosworth said he‚Äôs not worried about the results of the glitches.
‚ÄúObviously, I don‚Äôt love it, but I know the product works. I know it has the goods. So it really was just a demo fail and not, like, a product failure,‚Äù he said.

title: Lincoln Center‚Äôs Collider Fellows explore how tech could transform the performing arts
content:
At a time of high anxiety around technology‚Äôs impact on arts and culture, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts‚Äô Collider Fellowship is a program that welcomes multi-disciplinary artists to explore the opportunities that new tech presents for live performance and the performing arts.
Today, the famed New York performing arts center is announcing its second class of Collider Fellows ‚Äî a group of six artists working in areas from virtual reality to artificial intelligence to the immersive 4DSound System.
‚ÄúI love that they‚Äôre all really thoughtful people who are not just thinking about [the work] itself, but how it fits into a larger conversation in arts and technology,‚Äù said Lincoln Center‚Äôs vice president of programming Jordana Leigh.
Leigh added that she‚Äôs an ‚Äúeternal optimist‚Äù about how tech can benefit the arts. When asked about broader worries around AI, she countered that she‚Äôs excited about artists who can use AI as ‚Äúanother tool in their toolkit, like a mixer for sound or a paintbrush for paint.‚Äù She also suggested that for some artists, ‚Äútechnology is catching up to their vision, versus their vision catching up to this technology.‚Äù
To illustrate some of this potential, Leigh pointed to Dream Machine, a installation by one of the first Collider Fellows, Nona Hendryx.
Leigh said by using a combination of AI, VR, and augmented reality to immerse visitors, especially BIPOC visitors, in Afrofuturist environments, Dream Machine shows how art can help ‚Äúpeople who do not see themselves in technology to start seeing themselves in it ‚Äî particularly Black and Brown people, especially Black and Brown women.‚Äù
‚ÄúI think the more people who are part of the conversation, the more chance we have for it to be a good conversation,‚Äù she added.
The new Collider Fellows, selected through a nomination-based process, will continue exploring that potential. For the next six months, they‚Äôll be provided with studio space at Lincoln Center and Onassis ONX, along with a financial stipend and support from Lincoln Center staff.
The Collider Fellowship, Leigh added, is part of a broader umbrella of programs through which the performing arts center seeks to support artists in ‚Äúnon-transactional‚Äù ways.
Notably, the fellowship does not require participating artists to complete a final project or commission. Leigh said that the first class of Collider Fellows included one artist who completed ‚Äúfive or six prototypes‚Äù during the program, while another wanted to ‚Äútake this time to rejuvenate, read tons of books, do tons of research, slow down‚Äù ‚Äî she said both approaches are ‚Äúcompletely acceptable ways to use this fellowship.‚Äù
According to Leigh, many of the projects that emerged from that first class are ‚Äústill germinating,‚Äù and some could potentially be shown at Lincoln Center itself. And while Leigh described herself as ‚Äúdoubling down on location-based experiences,‚Äù particularly those that involve VR, AR, and extended reality, she also suggested that the Collider Fellows could help Lincoln Center rethink the ways it can reach audiences globally.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre closing the door to anything right now,‚Äù she said.

title: Updates to Studio, YouTube Live, new gen AI tools, and everything else announced at Made on YouTube
content:
At its annual Made on YouTube event this week, YouTube unveiled tons of new updates, features, and tools geared toward creators, including updates to YouTube Live, new ways to monetize, and more.
Studio updates include ‚Äúlikeness‚Äù detection and lip-synced dubs, and the company is offering new AI tools for podcasters to help promote their shows.
Here‚Äôs everything announced at Made on YouTube.
The company showed off new and updated tools to Studio, which creators use to manage their channels and track analytics. Updates include an inspiration tab, title A/B testing features, auto dubbing, and more.
What caught our attention is the ‚Äúlikeness‚Äù-detection feature, which was announced last year and made available to a few creators; it‚Äôs now in open beta. People will be able to detect, manage, and flag for removal any unauthorized videos using their facial likeness.
An AI-powered Ask Studio can guide users and answer questions about their account, and creators will be able to collaborate with up to five other people on one video, which is available to the audiences of all the participating video makers.
YouTube gave Live, its livestreaming platform, some updates as well, like letting creators play minigames to entertain viewers, broadcasting simultaneously in both horizontal and vertical formats, providing AI-powered highlights, reacting to live events, using a new ad format, and more.
The AI-powered highlights automatically select the best moments from a livestream to turn them into shareable Shorts, and a new ad format ‚Äî called ‚Äúside-by-side‚Äù ‚Äî runs adjacent to the main content, similar to a split-screen display, rather than interrupting the stream.
YouTube is bringing a custom version of Veo 3, Google‚Äôs text-to-video generative AI model, to Shorts, as well as a new remixing tool, an ‚ÄúEdit with AI‚Äù feature, and more.
With Veo 3 Fast, as the custom version is called, creators can apply motion from a video to an image, add different styles to their videos, and insert objects into the video with a simple text prompt. Creators can also transform the dialogue from eligible videos into catchy soundtracks for other Shorts using Google‚Äôs AI music model, Lyria 2.
YouTube Music got some updates as well, designed to deepen engagement between creators and their fans.
These include a countdown timer for new releases and a chance to offer fans ‚Äúthank you‚Äù videos, and the company is testing a pilot program for U.S. listeners that will allow them to access exclusive merchandise drops from artists.
Video podcast creators in the U.S. will be able to create clips more easily with AI suggestions, according to YouTube. And a new feature rolling out next year will offer a way to turn audio podcasts into video podcasts
YouTube is giving creators new ways to monetize, with brand deals and through the YouTube Shopping program, which lets creators earn money by featuring and tagging products in their content. YouTube will also now allow creators to swap out brand sponsorships in long-form videos.
Creators can also take advantage of auto timestamps for product tags, auto tagging for eligible items mentioned in videos, and a new brand link feature for Shorts. An AI-powered system will help identify the optimal moment a product is mentioned and automatically display the product tag at that time.
Shorts creators will soon be able to add a link to a brand‚Äôs site specifically for brand deals, and YouTube will proactively suggest creators who may be a good fit for brands in its creator partnerships hub.

title: Google isn‚Äôt kidding around about cost cutting, even slashing its FT subscription
content:
Google is ending its enterprise subscription to the Financial Times, and it‚Äôs not the only enterprise media subscription on the chopping block, sources say. The cuts reflect broader cost-reduction efforts at the search giant, even as the company reports strong financial performance.
Google has been implementing cost reductions across 2025, including eliminating 35% of managers who oversee teams of three people or fewer, and offering voluntary exit programs across multiple divisions since January. Finance chief Anat Ashkenazi signaled late last year that the company would continue to push cost cuts ‚Äúa little further,‚Äù a mandate that appears unchanged despite Alphabet reporting strong Q2 2025 results with $96.4 billion in revenue.
These cuts may save Google mere thousands; they also come as Google faces increasingly strained relationships with news publishers. August data from the trade association Digital Content Next showed median referral traffic from Google Search to publishers fell 10% between May and June of this year, with non-news brands experiencing 14% drops.
Major outlets, including CNN, Business Insider, and HuffPost have reportedly seen even sharper traffic declines (of 30%, 40%, and 40%, respectively), according to data from SimilarWeb.
Publishers attribute these declines largely to Google‚Äôs AI Overviews feature, which has reduced click-throughs to external websites from 56% to 69% since its launch, according to Pew Research. This spring, Pew analyzed data from 900 U.S. adults, six in ten of whom conducted at least one Google search in March 2025 that produced an AI-generated summary.
The traffic decline comes as Google has largely resisted content licensing, unlike rival OpenAI, which has signed deals with numerous major publishers including The Financial Times, News Corp, and Axel Springer. So far at least, Google has struck few deals, including one with the Associated Press and an annual Reddit agreement reportedly worth $60 million per year. (According to a new Bloomberg report, Reddit is now looking to renegotiate its contracts with both Google and OpenAI, with Bloomberg suggesting that Reddit sees its prominent role in search results and generative AI training as even more valuable than it first understood.)
Google reportedly began exploratory talks with 20 outlets about more content licensing deals this summer. Still, some might see Google canceling its FT subscription as akin to a plagiarist refusing to buy the textbook they‚Äôre copying from.
At a Fortune event earlier this month, the CEO of the largest digital and print publisher in the U.S. ‚Äî Neil Vogel of People Inc. ‚Äî didn‚Äôt hold his punches, calling Google a ‚Äúbad actor‚Äù and accusing it of using the same bot to crawl websites for its search engine as it does to support its AI features.
Google differs from other AI players by tying its AI training to search access, leaving publishers unable to block AI systems without also forfeiting search traffic.
‚ÄúFor a long time,‚Äù Vogel said at the event, ‚Äúthe deal was: ‚ÄòTake our content, build your search engine, send us back traffic‚Äô. That deal‚Äôs off.‚Äù
In a separate, scathing op-ed this summer, Digital Content Next CEO Jason Kint wrote that Google‚Äôs AI overviews are creating a ‚Äúzero-click‚Äù environment where ‚Äúall traffic dead ends at Google.‚Äù
Google did not respond to a request for comment.
Update: This story has been updated with information about Google‚Äôs content-licensing deals.
